TopicTitle: Does NVIDIA company produce graphic card or just design it?

Articles.Content:
My computer have MSI NVIDIA GT 630.

My previous card was Gigabyte GT 440 i get it as replacement for my Galxy Geforce 9800 which was fried:(

I just wonder does my first GPU GF 9800 was better than my current?

And does NVIDA produce GPU on their own?

I believe they do make a line of reference cards. I confirmed that with a quick Google search. A quick Google search also gave me the answer to your other question - it looks like there are benefits and drawbacks to each card, but in the end the 9800 is the better card.

Source: http://gpuboss.com/gpus/GeForce-GT-9800-vs-GeForce-GT-630

Since that answers your questions, let's everybody take a look at this, how Nvidia used some newfangled wizardry to replicate the lighting conditions of a famous moon landing photo.

http://www.slashgear.com/nvidia-fakes-the-moon-landing-with-maxwell-19347169/

Edited September 19, 2014 by Dkmdlb
It's good to see that finally someone debunked the debunkers in a very professional way even if it's a PR thing from nvidia.
It's my understanding that NVidia manufactures the actual GPUs and circuitry, but leaves it to other manufacturers to build the rest of it.

nVidia produces GPUs and provides a reference design, but the actual manufacturers make the PCBs, and usually sell both the reference design and their own, which sometimes use custom PCBs. Sames goes fro AMD if I'm not mistaken.

Since that answers your questions, let's everybody take a look at this, how Nvidia used some newfangled wizardry to replicate the lighting conditions of a famous moon landing photo.

http://www.slashgear.com/nvidia-fakes-the-moon-landing-with-maxwell-19347169/

Halfway down that page you'll come across this gem:

ABOVE: NVIDIA's breakdown of the Voxels of the scene. With VXGI, the truest lighting effects in graphics engine history can be rendered in real time. Imagine a game where you reenact the moon landing yourself!

Don't know about you, but I can't wait to play a game like that!

nVidia have no chip fab of their own, they farm the actual chip manufacturing out to TSMC. They design the chips and reference cards/cooling but do no manufacturing of their own.

Edited September 20, 2014 by Red Iron Crown

I just wonder does my first GPU GF 9800 was better than my current?

There is plenty of information on the internet to answer this question. Looking it up yourself is faster than asking us
